comments.commentBody:
Perhaps Ms. Johnson will provide readers with some good advice, but we won't see real improvement in the employment picture until structural and regulatory changes occur.

Jobs are going away forever because they can be done cheaper elsewhere or technology has reduced the need for workers. We must develop and fund new industries that will create new, long-term opportunities for workers of all ages. If the U.S. economy currently supports only one job opening for every five unemployed workers, no amount of personal career advice can turn that around.

Businesses also need to grow a spine and take chances on workers with general qualifications. Instead, they now insist that qualified candidates have every single last attribute listed in the job description. There's no on-the-job training and unpaid "internships" are the order of the day. Companies also need to jettison the biased younger HR managers who don't know what they don't know and wouldn't recognize a qualified older candidate if one was sitting on top of their computer monitor.

On the regulatory front, we need to find some way to strengthen age discrimination laws and prosecute those employers who will only hire people already employed.

I know of so many successful and talented boomers who are now unemployed or underemployed. It's a tremendous waste of human capital that can't be reversed by getting some pointers on your resume or advice on how to start a little business.

Is it true that I have to pay Social Security taxes if I start a small business, even if the only person who works in that business is myself? And, do I have to pay double, as both the employer and employee?

No question...just a statement.  I need to read articles like this regularly in order to remind me that no matter how much I long to retire early, I really need to hang onto my current secure but low-paying public service clerical job as long as I physically can.

Edith, I agree. I have caught snippets of Ms. Johnson's advice on television in the past, and have found it to be dubious. It really just seems to be the typical "You can do anything you want!" cheer leading, with nothing of substance.
I dont really buy entrepreneurs giving advice on starting a business when the business they started is giving advice on starting a business...

Excellent - thanks!
You have excellent points!  Couldn't agree more.

This ongoing assault on hard-working renters must stop. These policies bail out the propertied class at the expense of the working class. Indebted speculators and investors own the wage earner and the saver.

The whining of homeowners is no more acceptable than the entitlement mentality of bankers. One respondent here complained he couldn't qualify for a lower mortgage despite substantial equity and a recent 30 percent raise. Such hardship.

Another respondent chides people for being timid, uninformed investors and says their risk aversion is bad for the country.

This character is surely in the investment field, shilling more of the garbage that prompted people to take excessive mortgages.

Those timid, uninformed investors could be people who devoted their time and energy to a craft. Having to learn to be a mutual-fund trader on the side would have reduced their productivity on the job and their citizenship at home.

Emphasizing stocks and real estate as investments has diverted resources from business creation. QE3 does not realistically promise to change that. All it seems to offer is crippling inflation, offset by some breaks for property owners.

It's a pity that so-called liberals persist in genuflecting to the ownership society. They, including Dr. Krugman, are blind. He saw a bubble forming, did not properly investigate its origins and even suggested that it might be a good thing. If he couldn't diagnose the illness, he shouldn't be prescribing solutions.
And why do homeowners deserve help more than renters? When homeowners are generally wealthier than renters, and already get tax breaks from home ownership?

Neil, I did not mean to single out home owners for help. The line about bailing out Main Street came from Wall Street when they were begging for government help. See: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lkqb1pQrCcg never said Renters deserve help from this Great Recession. And so the poor, old, sick, homeless, hungry and the less fortunate among us. Unfortunately the wealthy and our government don't see it that way.
They would rather turn the people turn against each other to take the heat off of them. That is part of the gimmick they are using to attack teachers, fire and police for being overpaid and having too many benefits.
Instead the government should be helping people out of poverty and grow the middle class.
Trickle down does not work, it is a hoax. It just helps the rich get richer and that is what this mortgage buying program does.

Who exactly is going to benefit from the Fed buying up more junk mortgages from the banks?
The only way it would help the economy and the people whom, due to no fault of their own are suffering, is for the Fed to then write down the principle due on those mortgages for underwater homeowners.
The banks, brokers and insurance companies supposedly got debt relief to bail out Main Street. But as soon as the banks got theirs they forgot about the middle class. Self-righteously the banks now preach that it would be morally reprehensible if homeowners did not learn their lesson from their recklessness.
How many times do we have to bail out the banks and Wall Street before taxpayers say enough?
Never again should the taxpayers listen to the crocodile tears of bankers and Wall Street; and their political cronies.
Never.

It is so ironic that the people who lived modestly and saved their hard-earned money over their lifetime--so they could live off their principle in retirement--are being punished as badly as those that were reckless with their money.  What a tragedy.

the prudent,
the wise,
the responsible,
the savers :

Drop dead SUCKERS !

Sustained near zero interest rates are pushing older people who shouldn't be gambling with their life savings in to the stock market in a desperate attempt to generate an income stream. The really smart investors, who could afford to take a loss, started buying in March 2009 and they did quite well. The folks who are getting in now — well, it looks like they're "panic" buying because they're afraid of getting left even further behind.
At some point, something will happen which will signal that it's time for the smart ones to "take profit" and the bubble will burst again. Just like last time, the old folks won't know what hit them.

24.5 years, though I'm fond of bragging how we've been "happily married for nearly 125 years !".

Having mutually decided BEFORE marrying to forgo having kids has removed an immense amount of stress from our lives.

My wife is my best friend, in part because all of my best male friends have already passed away, and in part because she understands me so well that she takes me seriously only about half the time. We joke and tease each other a lot.

We are opposites. She's uber competitive. I just want everybody to have fun, and to not feel judged. She loves to meet new people. Just leave me alone, please. I'm a skeptic. She's the eternal optimist. She loves sushi. I call it BAIT.

The single best piece of wisdom I have gleaned over the past quarter century with my wonderful bride is this: You MUST have HUMOR and MUTUAL RESPECT in a domestic partnership, or the relationship WILL NOT LAST. And some trite sayings are still valid. Say "I love you" daily. Never go to sleep angry with one another (Or have good sense to apologize over coffee.) And keep the tradition of 'Date Night' alive.

Give each other 'breathing room' to pursue a hobby or interest that you both do not share. (My wife attained the rank of 5th degree black belt Master in Tae Kwon Do over the course of twenty years, despite my lack of understanding as to why she'd volunteer to be kicked and punched by others. And she'll never grasp the joy I experience from digging in the dirt and growing food in our backyard.)
Integrity
Been married for 26 years.  I always tell people the key to being married this long is to marry a very tolerant spouse!  Love you John.
There are no lasting relationships without forgiveness. That's more important in marriage than in anything else.

The second condition of the brilliance above is the age-old economic choice: guns or butter; how do our choices reflect our values? If obsolescence is part of the cause that stimulates demand, isn't it obvious that wealth, never obsolescene, doesn't have to be traded in or replaced? Increasing wealth through tax cuts doesn't increase demand! Capital formation long ago separated from its ties to labor; unlike Henry Ford, the new capitalists (Romney) doesn't need to produce units for the margin utility of profit. The excessive value of labor--stored as capital, extracted as fees, reordered balance sheets, raided pensions and benefits--is in private hands.

Because of powerful, private hands, Romney-Ryan attempt a moral arugment framed in political terms. Your taxes are going to Obamacare; your taxes are the source of a Democratic spending spree; your taxes pay welfare without work. Private rights are supreme, all else is socialism, dangerous, wrong. Their morality is tied to wealth, not reality.

In reality, each of us knows neighbors and families without health care who benefit; budgets can whack away at programs that don't have an immediate impact on the quality of life we share in common, and the citizens of states should be free to choose the path best to restore work for their unemployed. Freedom expands opportunity.

Many think freedom is only possible with a balanced budget; that we are shackled to debt. But debt is how we invest for tomorrow; like your mortgage.
You're welcome.  We left it for YOU to deal with.  So, what are YOU doing about it?

@That Guy "As a member of Gen X, let me make a plea on behalf of my generation and all the others getting on with things while you enter your seventh decade of staring into your collective navel: Get lost. Yield the stage already. Or failing that, do us all a favor and finally shut up."

Wow, hostile, much? Don't worry, the day will come when someone says all these things to you!

Enjoy youth while you have it, because with each passing day you are getting closer to the age that you so despise.

Eddie - Not all Boomers have defined pensions, obviously you have one. Even companies who had them converted most employees into a 401K decades ago. Haven't heard of anyone actually collecting a defined pension in most of the people in my age group (not too far behind you).
Did you work in public education or civil service?

Allen, what you're saying makes sense if the players are apolitical and honest. That's not the case here. Much of the anger you're hearing has to do with the fact that the money goes to the banks with *no* oversight, and the banks do *not* pump the money out into the economy. Do not.

Don't mistake your Samuelsonian fantasy world for reality. Pick up Machiavelli for a more accurate take on what's been going on.

1. Are you suggesting that economics students be taught what a rather small minority of economists think instead of what the majority of economists think are the fundamental principals of the field? It's fine to mention that there are some ten to fifteen percent of economists with other ideas, and to describe those ideas, but general discussion of any subject taught in universities and treated by peer-reviewed journals is going to assume a thorough understanding of the mainstream model. Those who deny those principles bear the burden of persuasion.

2. Mainstream economists certainly predicted the current crises. One of them wrote his prediction in the very newspaper sponsoring this forum. We don't have to stray from the middle of the road to find principles and models that are entirely consistent with the factual outcomes.

3. Mainstream economists today, and for years, have been suggesting "clear solutions", most of which involve the central authorities using both monetary and fiscal means to stimulate the economy. The problem has been that a lack of consensus among politicians and voters as to fiscal policy, a situation which early on produced some compromises that no one fully supported, and since then more polemic than policy. The FED has used its tools, but monetary policy can't replace fiscal policy.

4. See http://gregmankiw.blogspot.com/2009/02/news-flash-economists-agree.html for a list of principles and the percentage of economists who agree with each.

Amy, the banks receiving funds from the Treasury and FED are among the most regulated businesses in the country, and there is plenty of oversight designed to ensure the soundness of the banks and the security of depositors. That regulatory oversight does not, however, extend to encouraging banks to make loans because doing so would be good for the economy in general. The banks aren't lending because they are often too concerned about the their own balance sheets' ability to withstand stress testing and real stress from withdrawals and loan defaults. Here in Georgia bankers have many examples of banks that failed and of managers and directors whose reputations were destroyed, and they are consequently focused more on their bank's survival than on lending. The recent FED action addresses their fears by replacing shaky mortgage loans receivable on their balance sheets with FED reserves, a change it hopes will result in broader lending, greater employment and growth.

The FED action also effectively drives real interest rates negative by fostering an expectation of inflation. This makes the opportunity cost of sitting on cash balances higher, the hurdle rate of return on investment lower, and should therefore spur private investment.

It isn't Machiavelli who can best account for what we see in the economy today. An understanding of economics shifts the conversation to the far more interesting and controversial questions that lie beyond bogeymen and conspiracies.

Macroeconomics needs to be a mandatory class in high school. Rather than requiring voters to present a photo ID, let's instead require evidence of a passing grade in the rudiments of macroeconomics.

The depth of just plain ignorance of generally-accepted economic principles (not to mention the ignorance of the independence and role of the FED) revealed by too many of the comments posted on this article is appalling.

You can read any college freshman textbook on the subject in a couple of weeks. There are texts by Krugman on one end of the spectrum and by Mankiw on the other, and the two agree on almost every principle of macroeconomics. There certainly needs to be robust discussion of the FED's announcement, and certainly Krugman and Mankiw may have widely divergent views on that topic, but the starting point for any sensible discussion must be generally-accepted macro principles. Anyone who is unwilling or unable to put forth the minimal effort required to absorb the fundamentals needs to just be quiet, stand in the corner, and listen.

Ah, but what they don't quite understand is everything they now think has been around forever was the direct result of us, Baby Boomers! We paved the way.

At the age of 50, I decided to go back to school. I forget what class I was in, but the subject of the Baby Boom Generation was brought up. One kid asked "What is a 'baby boomer'? I raised my hand and said, That would be me. The professor and I both shared a knowing grin. The kid was totally out of the loop.

So, it was us, the kids of the Greatest Generation, who started to ask the hard questions and demand the answers. It was us with the great music and television series that broke the molds--All In the Family anyone? No rapper on earth can compare to The Beatles or the Rolling Stones.

D

Reading all the negative comments, mostly from younger-than-Boomers, is actually pretty amusing. Boy, are they peeved that someone else is getting the attention.

But, in reality, what I'm reading is not much different from the comments we Boomies were making in our own youth to the preceeding generations: you're old, you're out of touch, you think your generation was the best (but it's ours that's the best), your time is over, etc.

Well, kids, I'm old enough not to be bothered by your childish vitriol. I know it's hard for you to believe, but thirty or forty years hence, the next group coming up will be saying the exact same things to you. And that's a promise. I hope that by then you'll have ceased to take yourselves so very seriously, and will be able laugh at those clueless youngsters the way I am laughing at these.

Born in 1945 and happily collecting the "check".  I very much identify with the early boom times, especially the music and the peace/love feeling.  It really was a vibe that was palpable.  I am glad I was part of it and glad to be where I am now.  I continue to work for a nonprofit for word peace which is what was and is the most important theme of my life.

Expectations CAN fix balance sheets, if they lead firms to expect more demand and to hire to meet that demand, thus decreasing unemployment, and thus actually increasing demand, allowing those higher sales to materialize after all.

The economy is far from the production possibilities frontier at present. Lots of slack to bring back into production.

Let me guess... you're a Ron Pauler?!

It's funny how poorly MD's understand economics. You would think that after all of the medical school debt, they would have a better understanding of the cycles....

@ Ron,

I agree completely. Ignore my post, I hit the wrong REPLY link, it was intended for a blogger talking about the "debt crisis"...

I say it won't work but great that they are doing it: the sooner we see it is not working the sooner we can move on to fiscal policy.

To impact the economy via expectations you need to credibly promise to impact the economy in case the economy doubts. ("grab them by their [xxxxx] and hearts and minds will follow"). The Fed lacks any such tools even if it used a well defined target, it cannot grab. It can talk and do asset swaps. Equally well they could try to anchor expectations of a cold summer 2013, they can't deliver on that either.

Expectations cannot fix balance sheets, because the private sector cannot its own balance sheets, because the transactions inside the private sector don't change its net worth (unless they impact the values of real assets and stoke more bubbles, but this would require more private debt - not good). To fix balance sheets we need fiscal injections from the govt or massively lower taxes, ideally for the middle class and the poor. And a debt forgiveness/mortgage restructuring.

QE1 was somewhat effective because it was a back door fiscal policy: the Fed put a floor on prices that would otherwise have collapsed so it gave the holders free money.
